                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">Current Students</h2>


<h4 class="heading"></h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/images/bpatrologia-latina.jpg" width="320" height="240" alt="Migne's Patrologia Latina remains an indispensible resource for medieval and renaissance scholars. As with most of the library, students can borrow from this series. We also have them online, as with many other resources." class="medium-image float-right" title="Migne's Patrologia Latina remains an indispensible resource for medieval and renaissance scholars. As with most of the library, students can borrow from this series. We also have them online, as with many other resources." /><ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/current/ma_handbook"> </a><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/postgraduatestudy/taughtmasters/current-students" target="_self">KEY INFORMATION</a>, including: handbook, key dates, coversheets, dissertation proposal forms and coversheets, link to the Staff-Student Consultative Committee (SSCC)</li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree" target="_self">Modules </a></li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Coursework: students should always follow the submission guidance of the <strong>teaching</strong> department for the module that they are taking, <strong>except in the case of modules with an MDVLG code.</strong></li>
</ul>
<p class="p">In the case of modules (<strong>including the dissertation</strong>) with an <strong>MDVLG code</strong> students should follow History department submission guidelines. Guidance for submitting coursework (including penalties for late submission and overlength) is included in the Postgraduate Student Handbook (see 'key information' link above).</p>

  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {

    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/current/ma_handbook
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>

  $(document).ready(function(){
     //typeAhead();

    //close faceted navigation on mobile
    $('.mobileCloseAside').click(function(){
      $('.facets').toggleClass("show-facet");
      $('.off-canvas').toggleClass('spin');
    });
  })
</script>


    <script type="text/javascript" src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/silva/UCLDefaultLayoutV4/scripts/jquery.doc.ready.js"></script>

                        ga.type = 'text/javascript';

            <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MARS Modules</h2>
<p class="p">The Medieval and Renaissance Studies MA is a flexible degree that permits you to specialise
or take a broad interdisciplinary range of modules. Students should refer to the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/current-students/graduate-taught/modules/degree-structure" target="_self">degree structure</a> when selecting modules. Please ensure that you discuss your module selections with the MARS Degree Tutor (<a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/david-davray/david-davray" target="_self">Professor David d'Avray</a>).</p>
<p class="p">Please note that modules running in 2017/18 are dependent on student demand. If there is no or low demand from students, modules may be cancelled.</p>


<h4 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/skills_and_sources">Skills and Sources Modules</a> (MARS students only)</h4>






<h4 class="heading">Languages</h4>




<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlgl01">MDVLGL01 Beginners Latin for Research</a> (30 credits) - Normally taken together with: </li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/MDVLGL04" target="_self">MDVLGL04 Reading Medieval and Renaissance Latin</a> (15 credits) This can also be taken together with Intermediate Latin at King's College.</li>
</ul>


<h4 class="heading">Modern Scholarly Languages</h4>




<ul class="disc">
<li>MDVLGF02 Approved Modern Language (French)</li>
<li>MDVLGG01 Approved Modern Language (German)</li>
</ul>


<h4 class="heading">Medieval Manuscripts</h4>




<ul class="disc">
<li>MDVLG005/G004 Medieval Manuscripts and Documents (30 credits + 15 credits Skills &amp; Sources, normally taken together)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlge06">MDVLGE06/GE03 The Medieval English Book</a> (30/40 credits) </li>
</ul>


<h4 class="heading">Scandinavia </h4>




<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/intro-to-old-norse">SCANG013 Introduction to Old Norse</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/study/undergraduate/modules/year4-2017-18/4th-year-modules-17-18/scan4401-advanced-old-norse-" target="_blank">SCANGM15 Advanced Old Norse</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li>SCANGM05 Written Sources for the Viking Age (30 credits)</li>
</ul>


<h4 class="heading">Medieval and Renaissance Vernaculars </h4>




<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlgf">MDVLGF06 Medieval French Discourse: Middle French</a> (15 credits) </li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlgf">MDVLGF01 Medieval French Discourse: Old French</a> (15 credits) </li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlge05" target="_self">MDVLGE05 Old and Middle English</a> (30 credits) </li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlge05">MDVLGE08 Old English</a> (15 credits) </li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlge05">MDVLGE01 Middle English</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li>MDVLGG03 Medieval German Reading Course (15 credits)</li>
</ul>


<h4 class="heading">Medieval and Renaissance History</h4>




<ul class="disc">
<li>MDVLGH12A Identity and Power in Medieval Europe, AD 500-1300 (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/magic-middle-ages">MDVLGH11/GH02 Magic in the Middle Ages</a> (30/40 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlgh18">MDVLGH18A Writing History in Europe, c.900-1200</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/optional-courses/mdvlgh16">MDVLGH16/A A Global History of the
Middle Ages?</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ssees/masters-courses-2014-15/masters-courses-accordion/ssees/masters-courses-2014-15/current-course-outlines/hs_seesgh72/" target="_self">SEESGH72 Russian Monarchy: Court Ritual and Political Ideas 1498-1917</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li>HPSCGA20 Science and Medicine across Medieval Worlds (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/modules/core" target="_blank">ARTFGE01A Reframing the Renaissance</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/modules/forging" target="_blank">ARTFGE01B Forging the Early Modern</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/modules/unstitching" target="_blank">ARTFGE05 Unstitching the Early Modern: Archival and book skills</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/modules/web01" target="_blank">EDITG005 Web 0.1: Early Modern Information Culture c.1470-1750</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/modules/confessional" target="_blank">EDITG006 Confessional Cultures in the Dutch Republic &amp; England, c.1500-c.1700</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/current-students/course-options" target="_blank">HARTG080 Seeing Through Materials: Matter, Vision and Transformation in the Renaissance</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/ma-modules-2017-18/spang013a-sex-and-the-body-in-early-modern-europe" target="_blank">SPANG013A Sex and the Body in Early Modern Europe</a> (15/30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/ma-modules-2017-18/ELCSG023" target="_blank">ELCSG023 Men on the Moon: Cosmic Voyages in the Early Modern Period</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/ma-modules-2017-18/elcsg004-metamorphosis-the-limits-of-the-human" target="_blank">ELCSG004 Metamorphosis: The Limits of the Human</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/study/postgraduate-taught/ma-modules/ma-modules-2017-18/germ-g008-wolframs-parzival" target="_blank">GERM008 Wolfram von Eschenbach's 'Parzival'</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/study/undergraduate/modules/year4-2017-18/4th-year-modules-17-18/fren4115-medieval-french-literature/" target="_blank">FRENG115 Legendary Histories (Medieval French Literature)</a> (30 credits)</li>
<li>ARCLG345 <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/studying/masters/courses/ARCLG345" target="_blank">The Transformation of the Roman Mediterranean</a> (15 credits)</li>
<li>ARCLG534 <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/archaeology/studying/masters/courses/ARCLG354" target="_blank">Themes and Debates in Islamic Archaeology and Heritage</a> (15 credits)</li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
</ul>


<h4 class="heading">Information for non-MARS students taking MARS modules</h4>




<p class="p">If you wish to take a MDVLG*** module please contact the <a href="mailto:history-pg-enquiries@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">MARS administration team</a> to enquire about availability and to reserve a space. You should note that places for intercollegiate and interdepartmental students are allocated on a first-come, first-served basis. Priority is given to MARS students and to students on degrees affiliated with MARS. Please note that your place will not be confirmed until the first week of teaching.</p>


<h4 class="heading">Intercollegiate Options</h4>




<p class="p">It may also be possible for students to take intercollegiate modules offered on King's College London's <a href="http://www.kcl.ac.uk/schools/humanities/depts/history/study/grad/taught/med/" target="_blank">MA in Medieval History</a>, however this is subject to availability and the approval of the MARS Degree Tutor and the module tutor(s) at King's. Students should contact <a href="mailto:history@kcl.ac.uk" target="_self">history@kcl.ac.uk</a> to enquire. </p>

            <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                        _gaq.push(['t2._trackPageview']);
                        (function() {
                        var ga = document.createElement('script');
                        ga.type = 'text/javascript';
                        ga.async = true;
                        ga.src = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://ssl' : 'http://www') + '.google-analytics.com/ga.js';
                        var s =document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
                        s.parentNode.insertBefore(ga, s);
                        })();</script>
                
            
            <!-- End Google Analytics code -->

            <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>


            <!-- _______ Silva version 2.1.7 _______ -->

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MDVLGL04 Reading Medieval and Renaissance Latin</h2>

<h3 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/marie-pierre-gelin/marie-pierre-gelin" target="_self">Dr Marie-Pierre Gelin</a></h3>





<p class="p"><strong>Credits</strong>: 15</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Timetable</strong>: Wednesdays, 10-11am</p>
<p class="p"><strong>*<span class="underline">Please note that this module is for MARS students only</span>*</strong></p>
<p class="p">Each week these additional classes illustrate a specific genre of source and students are required to translate passages prepared in advance. This part of the module teaches students how to translate medieval sources, with an emphasis on the basic skills: using a standard classical Latin dictionary; using medieval or Renaissance Latin dictionaries; individuating the first things to look for when translating a sentence; the importance of knowing how to tune the effort to the needs (sometimes understanding the sense is enough, at other times a carefully articulated translation is essential).</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment</strong>: 1 X 1-hour unseen examination</p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">SCANG013 Introduction to Old Norse</h2>

<h3 class="heading">TBC</h3>





<p class="p"><strong>Credits</strong>: 30</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Timetable</strong>: TBC</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Please note</strong>: The module is taught alongside the undergraduate module, <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/prospective-students/undergraduate/year1-2015-16/1st-year-modules-15-16/scan1401-introduction-to-old-norse" target="_blank">SCAN1401</a>. Graduate students will receive five extra hours
of tutorials on topics to be determined in consultation with the lecturer.</p>
<p class="p">Old Norse, the medieval precursor to the modern Scandinavian 
languages, was once heard throughout Europe and beyond. During the Middle Ages 
Scandinavian ships travelled west to North America and east to Istanbul. The 
scope and variety of the Old Norse literary corpus matches the remarkable span 
of these journeys: myths and legends, love- and battle-poetry, prose narratives 
about kings, adventurers, poets and saints are all found in Old Norse. This 
module will introduce students to a wide range of Old Norse language and 
literature, situated within the broader context of the history and culture of 
Viking and medieval Scandinavia. Students will develop a good understanding of 
the basics of Old Norse grammar and by the end of the module will be able to 
translate medieval Icelandic prose and some forms of poetry. They will become 
familiar with key texts in the Eddic, skaldic and saga traditions, and will 
begin to explore ways in which contemporary scholarship can shed light on the 
complex but rewarding world of medieval literature.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment: </strong>1 X 3-hour examination<br /></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Preparatory Reading and Set Texts:</strong><br /></p>
<p class="p"> Students are advised to obtain a copy of A New Introduction to Old 
Norse – Part 1: Grammar, ed. Michael Barnes (London, 2004).</p>
<p class="p"> The two set texts will be Ari Þorgilsson’s Íslendingabók and Auðunar 
þáttr in A New Introduction to Old Norse – Part II: Reader, ed. Anthony Faulkes 
(London, 2008). Both volumes, as well as the accompanying glossary, are <a href="http://www.vsnrweb-publications.org.uk/" target="_self">available online</a>. </p>
<p class="p"> The following will offer a good introduction to the subject:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Margaret Clunies Ross, The Cambridge Introduction to the Old Norse-Icelandic 
Saga (Cambridge, 2010)</li>
<li>Heather O’Donogue, Old Norse-Icelandic Literature: A Short Introduction 
(Oxford, 2004).</li>
<li>Any of the texts in The Sagas of Icelanders: A Selection (London, 
2000).</li>
</ul>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered-->

    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();

  doc.close();
})();

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MDVLGH11: Magic in the Middle Ages</h2>
<p class="p"><strong><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/sophie-page/sophie-page" target="_blank">DR SOPHIE PAGE</a><br /><br /></strong>
Magic existed in diverse forms
in the middle ages: from simple charms to complex and subversive demonic magic.
Its negative characteristics were defined by theologians who sought to isolate
undesirable rituals and beliefs, but there were also many who believed that the
condemned texts and practices were valuable and compatible with orthodox piety.
This course will explore the place of magic in the medieval world and the
contradictory responses it evoked, with a particular emphasis on manuscript
sources. We will use translations of medieval magical works and scans of
manuscript images and texts. The aim of the course is not only to deepen
students’ historical understanding and further their analytical skills but also
to give students interested in planning their own research projects experience
in the techniques of reading medieval manuscripts.</p>
<p class="p"><br /><strong>Prerequisites</strong>: Students on this course must be studying, or have already taken a course in, Latin or a medieval vernacular language. Please contact the course tutor with any queries.</p>
<p class="p"><br /><br /><strong>Credits</strong>: 30</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment</strong>: 2 X 4,000 word essays<br /></p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

         class="content-box homepage-news-box">
        <h2 class="heading">MA Medieval &amp; Renaissance Studies</h2>


<h4 class="heading"> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/admissions" target="_self">Application for 2017 entry</a> is open!</h4>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">The History of Old and Middle English</h2>
<p class="p"><strong>Codes</strong>: MDVLGE05 (30 credits) <strong>OR</strong> MDVLGE01 'Middle English' (15 credits, term 1) <strong>OR</strong> MDVLGE08 'Old English' (15 credits, term 2)</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Module Tutor</strong>: Dr Vicky Symons</p>
<p class="p">This module aims to provide a reading knowledge of texts in Old and Middle English with the aid of a dictionary through a comprehensive study of basic Old and Middle English grammar, the reading of Seamus Heaney's translation of <em>Beowulf</em> and the translation of <em>The Dream of the Rood</em>, <em>The Wanderer</em>, from <em>Sir Gawain and the Green Knight</em>, from Malory's <em>Morte Arthur</em>, and <em>The Wakefield Second Shepherds' Pageant</em>.This module involves attendance at an undergraduate module, with additional tutorials for MA students.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment for MDVLGE05</strong>: Unseen three-hour written examination</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment for MDVLGE01</strong>: Unseen one and a half hour written examination</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment for MDVLGE08</strong>: Unseen one and a half hour written examination<br /></p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

    <div style="width: auto;float: none"
         class="content-box homepage-news-box">
        <h2 class="heading">MA Medieval &amp; Renaissance Studies</h2>


<h4 class="heading"> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/admissions" target="_self">Application for 2017 entry</a> is open!</h4>

                                        <a id="content" name="content"></a>

					<!--endnoindex-->
                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MDVLGE06 The Medieval English Book</h2>
<p class="p">May also be taken in conjunction with 15 credit<strong> </strong>MDVLGE11 <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree/skills_and_sources">Skills and Sources</a>: Medieval English Book - <strong>MARS STUDENTS ONLY</strong>)</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Credits</strong>: 30<br /></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Module Tutors</strong>: Professor Susan Irvine, Professor Richard North, et al.<br /></p>
<p class="p">The purpose of this module is to introduce students to the variety of skills required to read and interpret medieval manuscripts from the Anglo-Saxon period to the fifteenth century. Using important examples of books containing poetry and prose, students will be taught to read medieval handwriting, and how books were constructed and produced. The second strand of the module will include broader social and literary issues concerning medieval books such as patronage and ownership; readership, both male and female; the changing role of scribes and illuminators both in making books and helping to fashion assumptions about reading and interpretation; genre; and locality. By providing a range of material from the Anglo-Saxon period to the later Middle Ages, students will have the opportunity to compare books across both periods while still receiving specialised tuition on each. Old English will be studied in one term and Middle English in the other. Some prior knowledge of Old English or Middle English literature, but not both, is required for the module.</p>
<p class="p"><br /><strong>Assessment for MDVLGE06</strong>: 2 x 5,000 word essays</p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);

  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";

    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">Medieval French Discourse</h2>
<p class="p"><strong>Codes</strong>: MDVLGF06 (Middle French) and MDVLGF01 (Old French)</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Credits</strong>: 15 each</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Module Tutor</strong>: Dr Jane Gilbert</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Time</strong>: To be arranged at a mutually convenient time. Please contact <a href="mailto:j.gilbert@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Dr Gilbert</a>.</p>
<p class="p">This module blends language acquisition (morphology, syntax and vocabulary) with work on rhetoric, stylistics, context and linguistic usage. The module covers not just Old French (i.e. up to the thirteenth century), but also fourteenth and fifteenth century developments. We shall read, translate and discuss selected texts and extracts from a variety of linguistic areas which used northern French, the <em>langue d’oïl</em>. The texts will be a mixture of literary, sacred and historiographical works; there is some flexibility in the texts selected, depending on student interest. Students should have a good reading knowledge of modern French.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment for MDVLGF06</strong>: take-home test </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment for MDVLGF01</strong>: take-home test<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Preparatory reading</strong>: </p>
<p class="p">Jacqueline Picoche and Christiane Marchello-Nizia, <em>Histoire de la langue française</em>, 3rd edn (Paris: Nathan, 1999). Read the relevant portions of the first three chapters. (An electronic edition released in 2008 can be downloaded free as PDF on request from the publisher, <a href="http://www.vigdor.com/" target="_self">Vigdor</a>). </p>
<p class="p">Students may like to consult in preparation the helpful sites at the <a href="http://www.leeds.ac.uk/french/medfrench/" target="_self">University of Leeds</a> and the <a href="http://www.utexas.edu/cola/centers/lrc/eieol/ofrol-0-X.html" target="_self">University of Texas</a>.</p>
<p class="p">Students should obtain one of the following: </p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Claude Thomasset and Karin Ueltschi, <em>Pour lire l’ancien français</em>, Paris: Nathan, 1993 (slightly easier). </li>
<li>Sylvie Bazin-Tacchella, <em>Initiation à l’ancien français</em>, Paris: Hachette, 2001 (slightly more advanced).</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"><strong></strong></p>
<p class="p"> <em></em></p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";

    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MDVLGH16A: A Global History of the Middle Ages?</h2>
<p class="p"> <strong><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/patrick-lantschner/patrick-lantschner" target="_blank">DR PATRICK LANTSCHNER</a></strong></p>
<p class="p">Globalisation is often understood as a modern phenomenon, but medieval
historians are currently debating the extent to which it is feasible and desirable
to write a history of global connections and comparisons for the period between
500 and 1500 – an era during which new political formations emerged, religious
systems expanded and urbanisation thickened in many parts of Eurasia, while nomads
migrated across long distances, mercantile networks were consolidated and the
Black Death spread from Asia to Europe.</p>
<p class="p">The purpose of this module is to think conceptually and
methodologically about the challenges of writing a global history of the Middle
Ages and to question conventional understandings of periodisation, geographical
areas, and meanings of the ‘global’. Students can make original and
thought-provoking contributions to what is an evolving debate and are
encouraged to think about their own research interests within a global context. <br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Credits:</strong> 15</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment:</strong> 1 X 4,000 word essay</p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

            <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MDVLGH18A Writing History in Europe, c.900-1200</h2>

<h3 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/emily-winkler/emily-winkler" target="_self">Dr Emily Winkler</a></h3>





<p class="p"><strong>Credits</strong>: 15</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Timetable</strong>: Thursdays, 2-4pm, Term 2</p>
<p class="p">This module is concerned primarily with stories. In particular, students will
investigate how writers in the central Middle Ages told stories about their
past. What did they want to know and remember? What counted as valid historical
evidence? How important was the preservation of the past to identity in the
present? In what ways did choices about content, language and structure shape
the picture of the past? Was there a ‘Twelfth-Century Renaissance’ (C.H.
Haskins) or a ‘Crisis of the Twelfth Century’ (T. Bisson) in storytelling and
narrative? Students will have the opportunity to explore and compare written
material in a variety of genres, including annals, saints’ lives, medieval
biography, world history, poetry and narrative. Essential to the study of
historical writing is a consideration of impact and audience, so students will
consider medieval readers, transmission and manuscript evidence with visits to
library and museum collections.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment</strong>: 1 X 4,000 word essay</p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

                        var _gaq = _gaq || [];
                        _gaq.push(['_setAccount', 'UA-943297-1']);
                        _gaq.push(['_setDomainName', 'ucl.ac.uk']);
                        _gaq.push(['_setSiteSpeedSampleRate', 100]);
                        _gaq.push(['_trackPageview']);
                        _gaq.push(['t2._setAccount', 'UA-16328336-1']);
                        _gaq.push(['t2._setDomainName', 'ucl.ac.uk']);
                        _gaq.push(['t2._trackPageview']);
                        (function() {
                        var ga = document.createElement('script');
                        ga.type = 'text/javascript';
                        ga.async = true;
                        ga.src = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://ssl' : 'http://www') + '.google-analytics.com/ga.js';
                        var s =document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
                        s.parentNode.insertBefore(ga, s);
                        })();</script>
                
            
            <!-- End Google Analytics code -->

            <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MDVLGL01/MDVLGL07 Beginners Latin for Research</h2>

<h3 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/marie-pierre-gelin/marie-pierre-gelin" target="_self">Dr Marie-Pierre Gelin</a> &amp; <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/lucia-gunning/lucia-gunning" target="_self">Dr Lucia Patrizio Gunning</a></h3>





<p class="p"><strong>Credits: </strong>40 (MDVLGL07)<strong> OR </strong>30 (MDVLGL01)</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Timetable</strong>: Tuesdays, 11am-1pm and Thursdays, 11am-1pm<br /></p>
<p class="p">This module attracts students from many disciplines, including Classics, Ancient History, Medieval and Renaissance Studies, Theology and English. Students taking this module do not need to have any previous experience of learning Latin, although it may be useful to have some knowledge of a modern language.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment</strong>: in class tests (25%) and a three-hour unseen examination (75%)</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Preparatory reading</strong>: Students
taking the module should obtain a copy of: Susan Shelmerdine, Introduction to Latin, Focus Publishing,
2013, which consists of one single volume.
Copies can be purchased from Waterstones in Gower Street. Additionally,
students will need to obtain a dictionary, Chambers-Murray Latin-English
Dictionary is a good option.</p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">Skills and Sources Modules - 2017/18</h2>


<h4 class="heading">All Skills and Sources modules are worth 15 credits. These modules <span class="underline">MUST</span> be taken in conjunction with the matching parent module (see full module list).</h4>




<p class="p"> The MARS MA is distinguished from
other similar MAs by its special emphasis on the skills medievalists needs for
advanced research. The intensive Latin, Medieval English Book and
Manuscripts modules are salient examples but even selected modules that are not
explicitly skills orientated can be enhanced by a 15 credit ‘Skills and
Sources’ component designed to inculcate research techniques with special
reference to the content of the module. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The assessment for these modules, which
builds on modules students are already taking, focuses specifically on issues of
source criticism and evaluation and/or technical skills needed for advanced
research on such sources (e.g. palaeographical, linguistic etc).</p>


<h4 class="heading">Skills and Sources Modules' Assessment</h4>




<p class="p"> MDVLG005 Skills and Sources: Manuscripts and Documents</p>
<p class="p">MDVLGE11 Skills and Sources: The Medieval English Book</p>
<p class="p">MDVLGH92 Skills and
Sources: Identity and Power</p>
<p class="p">MDVLGH91 Skills and Sources:
Magic in the Middle Ages</p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

    <div style="width: auto;float: none"
         class="content-box homepage-news-box">
        <h2 class="heading">MA Medieval &amp; Renaissance Studies</h2>


<h4 class="heading"> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/admissions" target="_self">Application for 2017 entry</a> is open!</h4>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">An Overview of the Degree</h2>


<h4 class="heading">Our approach</h4>




<p class="p"> We emphasise intensive teaching in small groups; one-to-one
 tutorials outside of classes; and in providing students with all the 
support we can so that they can flourish on this stimulating and 
demanding course. <br /></p>
<p class="p"> This approach draws not only on our own expertise but also 
on our position at the heart of one the world's greatest collections of 
manuscript, library and museum resources. In particular, students have 
the exceptional privilege of being taught inside the British Library's <a href="http://britishlibrary.typepad.co.uk/digitisedmanuscripts/" target="_blank">Manuscripts Reading Room</a> on medieval and renaissance manuscripts of their own choosing, relating to their own interests. </p>
<p class="p"> Our location also means that MARS students are no more than seven minutes walk away from: The <a href="http://www.history.ac.uk/" target="_blank">Institute of Historical Research</a> (IHR), the <a href="http://warburg.sas.ac.uk/" target="_blank">Warburg Institute</a>, <a href="http://www.ull.ac.uk/" target="_blank">Senate House Library</a> and its <a href="http://www.senatehouselibrary.ac.uk/our-collections/research-collections/manuscript-and-print-studies" target="_self">palaeography</a> collection, the <a href="http://library.wellcome.ac.uk/" target="_blank">Wellcome Institute Library</a> and <a href="http://www.dwl.ac.uk/" target="_self">Dr Williams Library</a>.
 Students are introduced to these libraries, and we regularly organise 
guided trips to nearby museums with medieval and renaissance 
collections, such as the <a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/" target="_blank">British Museum</a>, the <a href="http://www.vam.ac.uk/page/m/medieval-and-renaissance-galleries/" target="_blank">Victoria and Albert Museum</a>, and the <a href="http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/" target="_blank">National Gallery</a>.</p>
<p class="p"> We also have a <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/mars-centre" target="_self">MARS Centre</a>, and are actively involved in a range of lively seminars in Bloomsbury, including at the Warburg, the <a href="http://www.history.ac.uk/events/seminars/114" target="_blank">IHR</a> and our own graduate-run Medieval and Renaissance Interdisciplinary Seminar.</p>


<h4 class="heading">Teaching</h4>




<p class="p"> Teaching is done in groups of about 3 to 12 students. In 
addition, students have individual tutorials in relation to essays, and 
have regular one-to-one tutorial meetings with supervisors when working 
on dissertations. All MARS teaching is provided by experienced 
academics. We place a premium on accessibility, and students will find 
teachers - however senior - available, and happy, to meet with them. </p>
<p class="p"> As across UCL, and particularly on MARS, students are 
taught by staff who are conducting their own research on the topics 
which they are teaching. Most modules therefore give students the 
opportunity to experience new research as it is produced. </p>


<h4 class="heading">Training</h4>




<p class="p"> MARS is designed particularly to equip students with the 
skills necessary for medieval and renaissance doctoral work, while 
retaining a very flexible curriculum.</p>
<p class="p"> All students must take one medieval or renaissance 
language. The selection ranges from Old Norse, Latin, medieval Italian 
and many more. Beyond this students are free to specialise or range as 
widely as they wish. <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree" target="_self">Modules</a> are often available in a range of full-year or half-year models, allowing for either preference.</p>
<p class="p"> For those who do want the skills needed for doctoral work, a
 range of 'skills' modules are central: 'Renaissance Texts', 'The 
Medieval English Book' and 'Manuscripts and Documents' (described by our
 external examiner as 'a jewel in the crown'). Students taking the 
full-unit options on Latin or Manuscripts and Documents have twice as 
much teaching-time than in equivalent MAs.</p>
<p class="p"> Finally, the dissertation provides the opportunity to apply
 these skills on independent research into primary sources, on a subject
 of students' choosing.</p>


<h4 class="heading">Funding</h4>




<p class="p"> There are a wide variety of funding opportunities open to 
MARS applicants, ranging from awards of full fees and maintenance 
scholarships to bursaries of several thousand pounds. The 
interdisciplinary nature of MARS means that we can enter applicants for 
numerous scholarships across the whole of UCL. In addition there is a 
specific Chattaway Bursary for medieval graduate students. For further 
details <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships" target="_blank">see the UCL funding website</a> or contact the <a href="mailto:b.karniely@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Programme and Admissions Assistant</a>. </p>


<h4 class="heading">Interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary</h4>




<p class="p"> MARS is an interdepartmental, interfaculty MA currently run
 by the History Department. It draws on expertise across UCL. 
Archaeology, Classics, English, French, German, History, History of Art,
 Italian, Jewish &amp; Hebrew Studies, Scandinavian Studies and the 
School of Slavonic and East European Studies all collaborate and 
contribute to the MARS MA. MARS students therefore have an exceptional 
range of modules and staff at their disposal. Students can consequently develop a course of study exactly appropriate to, and relevant, for themselves.</p>
<p class="p"> Further details are provided on other pages of this website,<strong> </strong>or email the MARS Degree Tutor <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/mailto:d.d'avray@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Professor David d'Avray</a>.</p>
<p class="p"> <em>Disclaimer: The information given on this website is 
given in good faith and is correct to the best of our knowledge. We may 
amend it as the need arises without notice. Please send corrections or 
suggestions to the <a href="mailto:history-pg-enquiries@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">MARS Programme Administration Team.</a></em></p>

                                <!-- begin: #col1 - first float column -->
                                <!--noindex-->

                        ga.type = 'text/javascript';

            <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">Admissions</h2>
<ul class="disc">
<li>

<h4 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/prospective-students/graduate-taught/medieval-renaissance" target="_self">APPLY!</a></h4>





</li>
<li>

<h4 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/ma_faqs">Frequently Asked Questions</a></h4>




</li>
<li>

<h4 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/funding">Funding</a></h4>




</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"><br />The usual entry qualification for an MA programme at UCL is an upper second-class or first-class honours or an equivalent qualification from a higher education institution in the European Union or overseas. In certain circumstances, the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/david-davray/david-davray" target="_blank"><strong>MARS</strong> <strong>Degree Tutor</strong></a> may consider applications from candidates with a lower second-class honours degree or equivalent. <strong>The deadline for applications for 2017/18 entry is 01 September 2017.</strong><br /></p>
<p class="p">Applicants who wish to be considered for funding within UCL must however must complete the UCL application process before they can be considered for funding. </p>
<p class="p">For enquiries about the admission procedure, please contact the <a href="mailto:b.karniely@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self"><strong>MARS Programme and Admissions Assistant</strong></a>. <br /></p>
<p class="p">For enquiries about the degree structure, modules, admission requirements, scholarships and similar matters, please contact the <strong><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/people/academic-staff/david-davray/david-davray" target="_self">MARS Degree Tutor</a></strong>.<br /> <br /><br /></p>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
<!--End center content area-->

(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

    <div style="width: auto;float: none"
         class="content-box homepage-news-box">
        <h2 class="heading">MA Medieval &amp; Renaissance Studies</h2>


<h4 class="heading"> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/admissions" target="_self">Application for 2017 entry</a> is open!</h4>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">Scholarships</h2>
<p class="p">The majority of Masters funding are administered centrally by UCL Student Funding. You can find the UCL funding search engine <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships" target="_blank">here</a>.<br /></p>


<h4 class="heading">Carol Chattaway Medieval History Scholarship</h4>




<p class="p">In addition, the History Department offers funding in the form of the Chattaway Medieval Scholarship. This annual scholarship is intended for an outstanding postgraduate scholar working in the field of Medieval History with a preference given to mature students and/or women. The scholarship is worth £2500. </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Application:</strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>You must have made an admissions application to study the MA Medieval and Renaissance Studies programme by 15 May</li>
<li>All candidates who have applied by 15 May will be considered</li>
</ul>


<!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered-->

  </ul>

    <div style="width: auto;float: none"
         class="content-box homepage-news-box">
        <h2 class="heading">MA Medieval &amp; Renaissance Studies</h2>


<h4 class="heading"> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/admissions" target="_self">Application for 2017 entry</a> is open!</h4>

                                        <!--Start center content area-->		
<!-- start main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
	<h2 class="heading">MA Frequently Asked Questions</h2>


<h4 class="heading">General</h4>








<h6 class="heading">How do I find out about the degree?</h6>


<p class="p"> First stop, check out the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree" target="_self">degree homepage</a>.
 On the degree homepage you will find the Degree Tutor, further details 
and the degree structure which lists all of the components of the degree
 and their weighting. Then you can check out the <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree">modules page and see 
what is available</a>. These usually change from year to year, but
 it will give you a good sense of what sort of modules are on 
offer. <br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Who are my primary points of contact?</h6>


<p class="p">The MARS degree is interdepartmental, with its administrative base in the department of History.<strong></strong><br /><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/mailto:http://history-pg-enquiries@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Programmes Administration Team</a> - You should contact this administration team within the History department for issues to do with module 
enrolment, general queries, or any practical issues concerning your 
degree.<br /><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/mailto:d.d'avray@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">Degree Tutor</a> - This is the leader of the MARS degree and acts as your Personal Tutor.  <br />Module Tutor - Your first point of contact for questions specific to the module.<br /></p>


<h4 class="heading">Application Procedure</h4>








<h6 class="heading">How do I apply?</h6>


<p class="p"> You can apply <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/prospective-students/graduate-taught/medieval-renaissance" target="_self">online</a> and in paper form,
 though we highly recommend applying online as it will be much easier 
and quicker to track your application (and the application fee is 
halved).<br /><br /><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/history/prospective-students/graduate-taught/medieval-renaissance" target="_self">For general application queries (including degree and English language requirements), click here!</a><br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">When is the deadline?</h6>


<p class="p"> Usually at the end of July for September entry. Some funding will 
require that you have applied and been accepted by a particular date. 
If you are applying for funding you should check with the funding body.<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Are there limited spaces?</h6>


<p class="p"> No. Provided you submit your application by the deadline, you will 
be considered for the programme.  <br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">I don't have an undergraduate degree in a Medieval subject, will my application still be considered?</h6>


<p class="p"> Yes. However, you should use the personal statement section to explain why you wish to do 
the degree. You should also aim to show 
that, though you have no formal qualifications in the subject, you have a 
strong interest and have pursued the subject independently.<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">I do not have the requisite 2:1 (or equivalent) undergraduate degree, will my application still be considered?</h6>


<p class="p"> In exceptional cases we may accept applicants with grades 
below the pre-requisite.  However, you will need to put forward a strong
 case. All such cases must be granted by the Dean of Students, so even 
if we support your application, we cannot guarantee your place. In the 
case of mature students, there may be slightly more leeway to account 
for changes in qualifications, but all such offers are still ultimately 
decided upon outside of the Department.<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">I don't have my transcripts yet, what do I do?</h6>


<p class="p"> Some students (usually those in the process of completing 
degrees when they apply) do not have transcripts sent out until the 
August before they are due to start their MA/PhD. You can make an 
incomplete application and be considered WITHOUT your transcripts. When
 prompted to attach your transcript(s) on the online application you can 
attach a document containing a brief explanation as to why you cannot do
 so, or a letter from your university with your marks achieved so far. This will then allow you to proceed and submit. However, we cannot issue an unconditional offer until all paperwork has been provided. We
 also cannot make an unconditional offer until your application is 
complete, including acceptable proof of language proficiency (where 
appropriate) and references.</p>


<h4 class="heading">Part-Time MAs
</h4>








<h6 class="heading">How does part-time study work? </h6>


<p class="p"> The part-time MA is the same programme as the full-time 
one, but spread over two years. Usually students will take between 60 and 90 credits' worth of taught modules in their first year. In the second year, students will then take between 30 and 60
credits' worth of modules and their dissertation. <br /></p>
<p class="p"> However, students can arrange the weighting of taught modules over the 2 years to suit individuals' needs.  <br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">When do modules take place?</h6>


<p class="p"> Taught modules are usually (but not always) two-hour seminars taught during 
the daytime. We do not teach in the evenings or at weekends. You can 
discuss modules choices with your Personal Tutor and create a programme of
 study that fits around your other commitments.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong>We do not offer distance-learning courses</strong> and class attendance is compulsory.  <br /></p>


<h4 class="heading">About Modules</h4>








<h6 class="heading">How are modules taught?</h6>


<p class="p"> Most modules are taught in two-hour seminars, once a week. 15 credit modules are generally for either term 1 OR term 2 and 30 
credit modules are generally (but not always) over both terms.  <br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">How are modules examined?</h6>


<p class="p"> This depends on the module, so check by clicking on the relevant module on the <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/ma-degree" target="_self">modules homepage</a>. Some modules may have an examination. However the majority of modules
 have 1 (15 credit) or 2 (30 credit)
 pieces of assessed coursework.<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Can I take modules in other UCL departments?</h6>


<p class="p"> Yes. As an interdepartmental degree, you are already free to take modules in all of the participating MARS departments, but you can choose modules outside of these too. Indeed one of the great advantages of the degree is that you have the opportunity to take modules from a huge range. We advise students to look at other UCL departmental webpages to 
see what is on offer. For some departments, you will need to seek 
permission before enrolling on a module. Some modules (usually because 
they are highly specialised) will not be open to students outside of the
 host department.<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Can I take modules outside of UCL?</h6>


<p class="p">


As part of your degree you can take modules at other University of London
institutions. If the module is not connected to your degree subject you
 will need to check the degree structure first. All module choices must
 be approved by your Personal Tutor first.</p>

         class="content-box homepage-news-box">
        <h2 class="heading">MA Medieval &amp; Renaissance Studies</h2>


<h4 class="heading"> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree/prospective/admissions" target="_self">Application for 2017 entry</a> is open!</h4>
